title: Quiz 7: Community Mobilisation
description: Understanding the process, importance, and challenges of mobilising the community for HBC.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'Community Mobilisation'?

options.text: The process of getting the community incorporated to fully participate in programmes for ownership and sustainability

questions.explanation: Mobilisation involves participation, ownership, and sustainability by the community itself.
questions.hint: Active involvement for the long term.

questions.question: Arrange the 4 steps of Community Mobilisation in the correct sequence:
Which of the following are considered key 'Community Mobilisers'? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Mobilisers are influential local figures like chiefs, religious leaders, and resource persons like TBAs.
questions.hint: People with influence IN the community.

questions.question: Community ___BLANK___ is essential for the sustainability of HBC programmes; without it, activities may die out when the health worker leaves.
questions.explanation: Ownership/Participation ensures that the community values the program and keeps it running.

questions.question: Which of the following is a factor that can HINDER community mobilisation?
questions.explanation: Resource mismanagement and lack of transparency destroy trust and hinder mobilisation.

questions.question: List one method mentioned in the text for mobilising the community.
questions.explanation: Methods include meetings, home visits, announcements in places of worship, or barazas.

questions.question: It is best to start mobilising the community from the bottom up, ignoring the leaders to empower the common people.
questions.explanation: The text states that to be effective, you should start from the top (leaders) to gain recognition and influence.

questions.question: What are the advantages of Community Mobilisation for HBC? (Select all that apply)

options.text: It facilitates the mobilisation of local resources
It ensures the government pays for everything

questions.explanation: Mobilisation reduces stigma, unlocks local resources, and empowers the community. It does not guarantee government funding.
